'''Willy (Wim) Van Grembergen''' (born 1947) is a Belgian [[organizational theorist]] and Professor of Information Systems Management at the [[University of Antwerp]], and Academic Director of the IT Alignment and Governance Research Institute.,<ref>[http://www.ua.ac.be/main.aspx?c=wim.vangrembergen Wim Van Grembergen], Universiteit Antwerpen. Accessed October 7, 2013.</ref> known for his work on IT governance.<ref>Webb, Phyl, Carol Pollard, and Gail Ridley. "Attempting to define IT governance: wisdom or folly?." System Sciences, 2006. HICSS'06. Proceedings of the 39th Annual Hawaii International Conference on. Vol. 8. IEEE, 2006.</ref><ref>Chand, Donald, et al. "A balanced scorecard based framework for assessing the strategic impacts of ERP systems." Computers in industry 56.6 (2005): 558-572.</ref> His recent book on IT Governance: "Enterprise governance of information technology: Achieving strategic alignment and value", Springer, 2009.
== Biography == Van Grembergen received his PhD in Applied Economics.<ref name="EST 1983">''Economisch en sociaal tijdschrift''. Vol. 37 (1983). p. 231</ref> After graduation he started his academic career as guest professor at the [[Katholieke Universiteit Leuven]]. He was faculty member at the [[Stellenbosch University]] and the Institute of Business Studies in Moscow.
Back at the University of Antwerp early 1980s Van Grembergen started as lecturer in Business informatics<ref name="EST 1983"/> and academic coordinator of the master programs IT-audit, and was Academic Director of the MBA Program from 1989 to 1995. Eventually he was appointed Professor of Information Systems Management and Chair of the Information Systems Management Department at the University of Antwerp, Economics and Management Faculty.<ref>[http://www.ua.ac.be/main.aspx?c=wim.vangrembergen&n=21902 Wim Van Grembergen resume] at ''ua.ac.be''</ref> Among his PhD students was Steven De Haes.<ref>''Dissertation Abstracts International: The humanities and social sciences''. 2008</ref> He was also associated with the [[Antwerp Management School]].<ref>Wim Van Grembergen (2004) ''Strategies for Information Technology Governance''. p. 382</ref>
== Publications == Van Grembergen authored and co-authored many publications in the [[Business/IT alignment]], [[Governance]] and [[Performance management]].<ref>[http://anet.ua.ac.be/desktop/irua/core/index.phtml?language=E&euser=&session=&service=acadbibart&robot=&deskservice=desktop&desktop=irua&workstation=&extra=05796~irua Van Grembergen, Wim (173)] at anet.ua.ac.be. Accessed October 7, 2013.</ref><ref>[https://scholar.google.com/scholar?hl=en&q=Wim+Van+Grembergen&btnG=&lr= Wim Van Grembergen] at Google Scholar.</ref> Books, a selection:<ref>[http://opc4.kb.nl/DB=1/SET=4/TTL=1/CLK?IKT=1004&TRM=grembergen,willy+van Van Grembergen, W. (Willy ; 1947-)] List of publications at National Library of the Netherlands.</ref><ref>[http://www.informatik.uni-trier.de/~ley/pers/hd/g/Grembergen:Wim_Van Wim Van Grembergen] at The DBLP Computer Science Bibliography.</ref> * Michel Daulie and Willy Van Grembergen. ''Ontwikkeling van administratieve systemen in BASIC''. Malle : De Sikkel. 1985. * Van Grembergen, Wim, ed. [http://www.sistemas.ith.mx/raymundo/Cobit/Idea%20Group,.Strategies%20for%20Information%20Technology%20Governance.%5B2003.ISBN1591402840%5D.pdf Strategies for information technology governance]. Igi Global, 2004.
Articles, a selection: * Van Grembergen, Wim, and Rik Van Bruggen. "Measuring and improving corporate information technology through the balanced scorecard." The Electronic Journal of Information Systems Evaluation 1.1 (1997). * Van Grembergen, Wim, [[Steven De Haes]], and [[Erik Guldentops]]. "[http://pdf.aminer.org/000/246/977/creating_business_value_through_business_it_alignment_shared_knowledge_commitment.pdf Structures, processes and relational mechanisms for IT governance]." Strategies for information technology governance 2.004 (2004): 1-36. * [[De Haes, Steven]], and Wim Van Grembergen. "[http://www.antwerpmanagementschool.be/media/287500/IT%20Gov%20structures%20IT%20business%20alingnment%20in%20BE%20financial.pdf IT governance structures, processes and relational mechanisms: achieving IT/business alignment in a major Belgian financial group]." System Sciences, 2005. HICSS'05. Proceedings of the 38th Annual Hawaii International Conference on. IEEE, 2005. * Van Grembergen, Wim. "Introduction to the Minitrack." System Sciences, 2007. HICSS 2007. 40th Annual Hawaii International Conference on. IEEE, 2007.
== References == {{reflist|2}}
== External links == * [http://www.ua.ac.be/main.aspx?c=wim.vangrembergen Wim Van Grembergen], Universiteit Antwerpen
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Van Grembergen, Wim}} [[Category:1947 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Belgian business theorists]] [[Category:Katholieke Universiteit Leuven faculty]] [[Category:Stellenbosch University faculty]] [[Category:University of Antwerp faculty]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Édouard,
Baron Empain | image = Edouard Empain.GIF | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Édouard Louis Joseph Empain | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1852|09|20}} | birth_place = [[Belœil]], Belgium | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|1929|07|22|1852|09|20}} | death_place = [[Woluwe]], Belgium | nationality = [[Belgian]] | other_names = | known_for = Building [[Paris Métro]] and town of [[Heliopolis (Cairo Suburb)|Heliopolis]] | occupation = Industrialist, General and amateur Egyptologist }} '''Édouard Louis Joseph, Baron Empain''' (20 September 1852 – 22 July 1929), was a wealthy Belgian engineer, entrepreneur, financier and [[industrialist]], as well as an amateur [[Egyptologist]]. During [[World War I]] he became a known Major-General. ==Early life== Empain was born at [[Belœil]], [[Belgium]], and was the son of schoolteacher[http://www.egy.com/community/95-05-13.shtml THE BELGIANS OF EGYPT, 13 May 1995] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060719234702/http://egy.com/community/95-05-13.shtml |date=19 July 2006 }} at www.egy.com François Julien Empain and his wife Catherine (née Solivier). He went into business with his brother, [[Baron François Empain]] and other family members, and amassed a great fortune. Empain began his career a draughtsman at a metallurgical company, Société métallurgique, in 1878,[http://www.wallonie-en-ligne.net/1995_Cent_Wallons/Empain_Edouard.htm EMPAIN Edouard] at www.wallonie-en-ligne.net and became involved in railway construction when he noticed that transport infrastructure in the countryside was inadequate. After success in Belgium with the [[Liège (city)|Liège]]-[[Jemappes|Jemeppe]] line, his companies developed several railway lines in France, including the creation of the [[Paris Métro]]. Because he felt that he depended too much on the banks for his industrial plans, in 1881 he founded his own bank, Banque Empain, which later became the Belgian Industrial Bank (''"Banque Industrielle Belge"''). The Empain group of companies expanded greatly throughout the 1890s, constructing electric urban tramlines in Europe, [[Russian Empire|Russia]], [[Qing Dynasty|China]], the [[Belgian Congo]], and in [[Cairo]], [[Khedivate of Egypt|Egypt]]. Desiring to also be independent of electricity producers, Empain also was involved in forming a number of electricity companies to power his projects. ==Egypt== [[Image:Baron Empain Palace.jpg|150px|thumb|[[Baron Empain Palace]] (''Qasr Al Baron''), [[Heliopolis (Cairo Suburb)|Heliopolis]], Egypt.]] Édouard Empain arrived in Egypt in January 1904, intending to rescue one of the projects of his company [[Chemins de Fer de la Basse-Egypte|''S.A. des Chemins de Fer de la Basse-Egypte'']]; being the construction of a railway line linking [[Mansoura, Egypt|Mansourah]] (on the [[Nile]] river) to [[El Matareya|Matariya]] (on the far side of [[Lake Manzala]] from [[Port Said]]).[http://www.booneshares.com/BELGIANCOMPANIESINEGYPT.htm BELGIAN COMPANIES IN EGYPT*] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070314030229/http://www.booneshares.com/BELGIANCOMPANIESINEGYPT.htm |date=14 March 2007 }} at www.booneshares.com Despite losing the railway contract to the British, [[Empain]] stayed on in Egypt. In 1906, Empain established the [[Cairo Electric Railways and Heliopolis Oases Company]], which bought a very large stretch of desert (25 square kilometres) to the northeast of Cairo at a low price from the Egyptian government. Commencing in 1906 this company proceeded with the building of the new town of [[Heliopolis (Cairo Suburb)|Heliopolis]], in the desert ten kilometers from the center of [[Cairo]]. It was designed as a "city of luxury and leisure", with broad avenues and equipped with all necessary conveniences and infrastructure; water, drains, electricity, hotel facilities, such as the Heliopolis Palace Hotel (formerly the [[presidential palace]] of ex-President [[Hosni Mubarak]]) and Heliopolis House, and recreational amenities including a golf course, racetrack and park. In addition, there was housing for rent, offered in a range of innovative design types targeting specific social classes with detached and terraced villas, apartment buildings, tenement blocks with balcony access and workers' bungalows. Today, Baron Empain is perhaps best known by modern visitors to Egypt for the building of a palace (the ''Palais Hindou'') in the Avenue des Palais (renamed Orouba Avenue following the [[Egyptian Revolution of 1952]]) [[Heliopolis (Cairo Suburb)|Heliopolis]], Egypt. Inspired by [[Angkor Wat]] in Cambodia and the [[Hindu]] temples of [[Orissa, India|Orissa]],{{Citation needed|date=February 2007}}, the [[Baron Empain palace]] was designed by French architect [[Alexandre Marcel]] (1860–1928) and decorated by Georges-Louis Claude (1879–1963), with construction being completed in 1911. In 1905, Empain assisted the Belgian government in the purchase of an [[Old Kingdom]] [[mastaba]] for the royal museum in [[Brussels]], of which he was a benefactor. In 1907 he received the title of [[Baron]], and also suggested to Belgian Egyptologist [[Jean Capart]] that he excavate at Heliopolis, where his building constructions were underway. He also made it possible for Capart to acquire some fine ancient artefacts for the Brussels Museum. ==Military Career== [[File:Photographie - Général Empain.JPG|thumb|Major-General Baron Empain]] During [[World War I]], he was given the rank of general and directed armaments production at Paris and [[Le Havre]] for the Belgian army. He died in [[Woluwe]], [[Belgium]], and was buried in the Our Lady of Heliopolis Basilica (''Basilique Notre-Dame d'Héliopolis'').{{cite news|last=Cook|first=William|title=Surrounded by barbed wire and shrouded in superstition: The crumbling Egyptian palace of tragic Belgian millionaire who raised a city from the desert|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2201662/Baron-Empain-Palace-A-Belgian-millionaire-Egyptian-palace-shrouded-superstition.html|accessdate=3 January 2013|newspaper=Daily Mail|date=12 September 2012}} He was succeeded as baron by his son, Jean Empain, who married American [[burlesque]] performer Rozell Rowland (sometimes Rozelle Rowland). They entertained frequently at the Heliopolis. Jean, 2nd Baron Empain, was succeeded by their son, [[Édouard-Jean Empain]]. == Honours == * {{Flag|Kingdom of Belgium}}: ** Honorary [[Aide-de-camp]] of the HM the King.http://www.ars-moriendi.be/EMPAIN.HTM ** [[War Cross (Belgium)|War Cross]] ** Grand Officer in the [[Order of Leopold (Belgium)|Order of Leopold]]. * {{Flag|Kingdom of Egypt}}: Knight grand Cross of the [[Order of the Nile]]. * {{Flag|Kingdom of Spain}}: Knight grand Cross of the [[Order of Isabella the Catholic]] * {{flag|United Kingdom}}: Companion of the [[Order of the Bath|Most Honourable Military Order of the Bath]]. * {{Flag|France}}: Commander of the [[Legion of Honour]]. ==See also== * The town of [[Kindu]] in the [[Belgian Congo]] was known as ''Port Empain''. * [[Cairo Electric Railways & Heliopolis Oases Company|Heliopolis Oasis Company]] * [[Heliopolis (Cairo Suburb)|Heliopolis]] ==Notes== {{reflist}} == Further reading == * Howard Shakespeare, [https://web.archive.org/web/20070314030229/http://www.booneshares.com/BELGIANCOMPANIESINEGYPT.htm Belgian Companies in Egypt], (published by the [http://www.scripophily.org International Bond & Share Society], 1998). * Van Loo, Anne & Bruwier, Marie-Cécile (eds.), ''Héliopolis'', Brussels: Fonds Mercator, 2010, 229 p., richly illustrated {{ISBN|978-90-6153-930-8}}. * ''Une Donation d'antiquités égyptiennes aux Musées royaux de Bruxelles'', (1911). ==External links== *An [https://web.archive.org/web/20080325224028/http://egy.com/landmarks/maadi/96-11-16.shtml article from the ''Egyptian Mail''], by Samir Raafat, on the founding of the Cairo Electric Railways & Heliopolis Oases Company. *An [https://web.archive.org/web/20100804000901/http://www.egy.com/landmarks/97-05-01.shtml article from the ''Egyptian Mail''], by Samir Raafat. on the building of the Palace of the Baron Empain. *[http://archnet.org/library/sites/one-site.tcl?site_id=3638 A selection of images of the palace of Baron Empain] (in Heliopolis, Egypt) {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Empain, Baron}} [[Category:1852 births|Empain, Baron Edouard Louis Joseph]] [[Category:1929 deaths|Empain, Baron Edouard Louis Joseph]] [[Category:Belgian businesspeople|Empain, Baron Edouard Louis Joseph]] [[Category:Belgian Egyptologists|Empain, Baron Edouard Louis Joseph]] [[Category:Belgian bankers]] [[Category:Belgian engineers]] [[Category:Barons Empain| ]] [[Category:Walloon people]] [[Category:Companions of the Order of the Bath]] [[Category:Knights Grand Cross of the Order of Isabella the Catholic]] [[Category:Commandeurs of the Légion d'honneur]] [[Category:Recipients of the Croix de guerre (Belgium)]] [[Category:Belgian Army generals of World War I]]
